title: Mauricio Pochettino warned it would be 'silly' to leave Tottenham for Manchester United
text:
Mauricio Pochettino would be ‘silly’ to leave Tottenham for Man Utd, according to Harry Redknapp (Picture: Getty)

Mauricio Pochettino would be ‘silly’ to leave Tottenham for struggling Premier League giants Manchester United, according to Harry Redknapp.

The Argentine manager, who led Spurs to the Champions League final last season, has been repeatedly linked with a move to Old Trafford over the past three years.

Tottenham have endured a dismal start to the season, winning just three of their eight league fixtures to sit ninth in the Premier League, 13 points off unbeaten leaders Liverpool.

Redknapp believes the Argentine manager should stay put (Picture: Getty)

The Red Devils are also struggling, taking just eight points from their first nine matches to spark speculation over Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s future.

Pochettino would be an obvious candidate to replace Solskjaer if Manchester United opted for a change but Redknapp says he would be ‘silly’ to leave Spurs at this stage.

He told the Daily Mirror: ‘Listen, he’s the manager of a London club, a great place to live, I’m sure he’s earning an absolute fortune, they have a great training ground, they have a great stadium and he has great players.

‘Where does he go better than Tottenham? Liverpool don’t want him, they’ve got Jurgen Klopp. Pep (Guardiola) is at Manchester City, they don’t want him.

‘OK, if Real Madrid comes up he may fancy going to Spain, obviously being from Argentina. The language wouldn’t be a problem and living in Madrid would be very nice.

‘Managing a club like Real Madrid, if that came up I’m sure it would be a difficult one for him to turn down.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is under huge pressure at Manchester United (Picture: Getty)

‘But other than that, I don’t see where he goes. Manchester United? Maybe but Pochettino is not silly, he knows he’s got a massive rebuilding job there.’

Tottenham were knocked out of the Carabao Cup by League Two side Colchester United last month and suffered a demoralising 3-0 defeat to Brighton before the international break.

Spurs are expected to oversee a clear-out in January and Redknapp fears a number of players have had their heads turned.

‘The problem they’ve got is that those players who wanted a move are maybe not playing particularly well,’ he added.

‘Eriksen’s form has not been what it was. I think he’s a great player. There are a few of them who haven’t been playing so well.

‘The two centre-halves as well (Vertonghen and Alderweireld) – the two Belgian boys – they have to start performing as well.’
